content.value: In this session, we will learn how to create, copy, move, rename, and delete files and directories in the Linux file system. These skills are essential for managing your files effectively.

value: Opens a text editor to create or edit a file directly from the terminal.
Creates a new directory with the specified name (if it doesn't exist).

content.description: Creates and open text editor with an empty file named 'newfile.txt'

value: Copies files or directories from one location to another.
Copies a directory and its contents recursively, including subdirectories.
Moves or renames files and directories from one location to another.
Specifies the target directory for moving a file or directory.
Displays detailed information about the moves and renames performed.

content.value: A directory is a folder that holds files and other directories.
content.example: Example: report.txt is a file and Documents is a directory.

value: Renames a file or directory by specifying its old name, new name, and destination directory (if needed).
Creates a backup copy of the original file before renaming it.
Prompts for confirmation before overwriting an existing file with the same name.
Removes files or directories from the Linux file system.
Removes a directory and its contents recursively, including subdirectories.
Forces removal of files and directories without prompting for confirmation. Use with caution!

content.value: A file is a container used to store data such as text, images, or programs.
content.example: Example: notes.txt is a text based file.

steps: Create a new file named myfile.txt in your home directory using the nano command.
Create a new directory called test_directory in your home directory using the mkdir command.
Copy the myfile.txt file to the test_directory directory using the cp command.
Move the myfile.txt file from the test_directory directory back to your home directory using the mv command.
Rename the myfile.txt file in your home directory to new_filename.txt.
Remove the myfile.txt file from your home directory using the rm command.
Remove the test_directory directory using the rm -r command.
